summary.value:
MODIFYING REPLICATION OF BOWES AND KATZ (2015)

Hillel Steinmetz and Anne Henly

The following document details shifting our research focus towards a new research question and making slight modifications to the experiment.

We would like to register an analysis that we will run on data pooled from our collected data and data we hope to collect over the next few weeks. After running In looking at the data, we noticed that reading metaphor affected monolinguals and bilinguals differently (a self-disclosed measure). A 2 x 2 ANOVA on RMET performance and self-identification as monolingual or bilingual resulted in a significant interaction effect. Looking at group means, we believe this interaction effect to be driven by monolingual speakers assigned to either the metaphor or literal condition. On the other hand, bilinguals who read metaphorical language seems to, if anything, score lower on the RMET, although we believe that this observation will have to be confirmed with more data collection. 

Overall, we predict that reading metaphorical language has a differential effect on RMET performance for monolingual English speakers and bilingual English speakers. We predict that monolinguals who read metaphorical sentences will perform better on the RMET than monolinguals who read literal sentences. We also predict that there will be no significant difference for RMET performance between literal and metaphor grouped bilingual speakers. 

Therefore, our new dependent variables will be Reading the Mind in the Eyes Task (RMET) scores and whether a participant speaks another language as identified through a demographics survey at the end of the experiment.

In addition to running a t-test on RMET scores between literal and metaphorical language groups, we will also perform a t-test on RMET scores for monolingual speakers. We will also conduct a 2 x 2 ANOVA that will check whether there is an interaction effect between the two conditions (literal and metaphor reading tasks) and identification as a monolingual or bilingual on RMET performance. A posthoc Tukey HSD test will determine where this difference originates. We will also perform a t-test on RMET scores for monolingual speakers to verify that there is an effect within this group. Additionally, we hope to run a 2 x 5 ANOVA on condition and language proficiency (which we anticipate dividing into 5 levels) and RMET scores on our new sample of participants.

Additionally, to relate to the existing literature on bilingualism and executive control, we will have participants perform a modified Stroop task (1935). According to van den Noort et. al. (2019), this task was one of the cognitive tasks in which bilinguals consistently had an advantage over monolinguals. We will run the manual version of the task (responses are key presses) as well as a modified version of the emotional Stroop task created by Shintel, Nusbaum, and Cacioppo which uses social words (2006). The two tasks will be counterbalanced for the order they will be given to participants. The manual Stroop task will help us evaluate the role of executive control on RMET performance and how metaphorical language might affect executive control in monolinguals and bilinguals. The Social Stroop task uses the same color identification task as the Stroop task, displays emotional and social words instead of color words. We are using the Social Stroop task since it could reveal whether metaphor primarily primes attention to social cues or whether primarily cultivates intimacy. While, based on previous research, metaphor might prime attention to social cues as evidenced by the RMET, it is unclear whether it is the fact that metaphor cultivates intimacy which drives this effect, or whether it is some other process. Indeed, Shintel, Nusbaum, and Cacioppo (2006) found that lonelier individuals showed greater interference effects on negative social words, meaning that they pay more attention to social cues. In other words, social attention is not necessarily correlated with whether a person experiences intimacy. The addition of this test might help clarify what aspects of metaphor are driving increased performance on the RMET. Additionally, it is important to account for loneliness and so we will have participants respond to the UCLA Loneliness Scale after the PANAS, IRI, and Imagined Speaker Questionnaire, but before the demographics questionnaire. This placement was chosen since the Stroop and Social Stroop tasks might cause participants to feel lonely given the nature of the color identification task, and the surveys in between might alleviate this possible effect. 

Since our new analysis involves asking participants about their linguistic background, we believe that we need a more detailed approach to determining a participant's native language. Therefore, we've expanded our demographic survey to include a modified version of Marian, Blumenfeld, and Kaushanskaya’s (2007) LEAP-Q Questionnaire to collect more detailed information about the languages that our participants use and on what occasions do they use particular languages. This way, we can systematically describe which participants are monolingual and bilingual, and score participants based on their proficiency in other languages.

Additionally, we would like to state that we may modify our exclusion criteria. While we anticipate using the same as those used in our replication of Bowes and Katz (2015) (see https://osf.io/wr3mq/), we came to understand that these criteria may be eliminating otherwise important observations. There are several reasons why we may modify these exclusion criteria (eliminating too many observations, the spread being too wide, a tail being informative). This is especially true when considering the suggestions of Baayen and Milin (2010) in eliminating less than 15% of data overall, and less than 5% should the tails be thick. Should we modify these criteria, we will state our motivations for modifying these criteria on our OSF page (in addition to providing all the data needed to replicate our analyses).

Finally, our future participants will be students recruited from the University of Chicago students.

References

Cohen, T. (1978). Metaphor and the Cultivation of Intimacy. Critical Inquiry, 5(1), 3–12. 

Baayen, R. H., & Milin, P. (2010). Analyzing reaction times. International Journal of 
Psychological Research, 3(2), 12-28.

Bowes, A. & Katz, A. (2015). Metaphor enhances intimacy and temporarily enhances theory of 
mind, Memory and Cognition 43: 953. 

Fan, S. P., Liberman, Z., Keysar, B., & Kinzler, K. D. (2015). The exposure advantage: Early 
exposure to a bilingual environment promotes effective communication. Psychological Science, 26(7), 1090-1097.

Gernsbacher, M. A., Keysar, B., Robertson, R. R., & Werner, N. K. (2001). The Role of Suppression and Enhancement in Understanding Metaphors. Journal of memory and language, 45(3), 433–450. 

Horton, William S. (2007) Metaphor and readers’ attributions of intimacy, Memory &  Cognition, 35: 87. 

Marian, V., Blumenfeld, H. K., & Kaushanskaya, M. (2007). The Language Experience and Proficiency Questionnaire (LEAP-Q): Assessing language profiles in bilinguals and multilinguals. Journal of Speech, Language, and Hearing Research.

van den Noort, M., Struys, E., Bosch, P., Jaswetz, L., Perriard, B., Yeo, S., Barisch, P., Vermeire, K., Lee, S. H., & Lim, S. (2019). Does the Bilingual Advantage in Cognitive Control Exist and If So, What Are Its Modulating Factors? A Systematic Review. Behavioral sciences (Basel, Switzerland), 9(3), 27. 

Shintel H., Nusbaum H.C., Cacioppo J.T.. Accentuate the negative, eliminated the positive? Individual differences in attentional bias to positive and negative information. Presented at the 47th Annual Meeting of the Psychonomic Society; Houston, Texas. Nov. under review.

Stroop J.R. Studies of interference in serial verbal reactions. J. Exp. Psychol. 1935;18:643–662.

attributes.title: Replication of Bowes and Katz (2015)
attributes.description: Replicating Bowes and Katz (2015) "Metaphor creates intimacy and temporarily enhances theory of mind" with some additional measures.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Russia has committed between $200 million and $250 million USD per year to significantly strengthen its cyber-offensive capabilities. These investments are not exceptions but rather part of a global trend -- countries have been spending significant resources to implement bureaucratic changes to their cyber apparatus. However, conditions under which such changes can conceivably deter adversaries are fairly limited, and this raises the question: Is this increased investment actually warranted by the threat of cyber attacks? After all, security measures are often a form of window-dressing, intending just to make the people feel more secure without doing much about the underlying threat. An example of this is TSA screening measures. In worst case, governments may inflate cyber threats in order to encroach on civil liberties by increasing surveillance. For example, have the American people started feeling more secure after the U.S. government threatened to retaliate against cyber attacks with all its means? Does the fact that the Brazilian government has created the Centre for Cyber-defense make Brazilian citizens feel more secure from external cyber threats or more frightened of the government’s increasing ability to monitor and surveil citizens online behavior? And how does the public perceive such increasing in cyber offensive capability in the countries at which these deterrence measures are directed? In a series of four survey experiments, this research will investigate how the public perceives the increased government spending on cyber security. The first experiment tests the specific mechanisms undergirding citizens’ perception of their own state’s increased cyber capability through looking at the reactions of Americans and Russians. The second experiment tests the mechanisms that explain citizens’ perception of increased cyber capability by the adversarial government, this time examining the Russian public’s reaction to increased U.S. cyber capability intended to deter Russian attacks, and vice versa.

q16.value: Explained in the attached pre-analysis plan

q17.value: Explained in the attached pre-analysis plan

q27.value: Researchers, I will also use the survey firms that will distribute the links to my survey.

And how does the public perceive such increasing in cyber offensive capability in the countries at which these deterrence measures are directed? In a series of four survey experiments, this research will investigate how the public perceives the increased government spending on cyber security. The first experiment tests the specific mechanisms undergirding citizens’ perception of their own state’s increased cyber capability through looking at the reactions of Americans and Russians. The second experiment tests the mechanisms that explain citizens’ perception of increased cyber capability by the adversarial government, this time examining the Russian public’s reaction to increased U.S. cyber capability intended to deter Russian attacks, and vice versa.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

analyses.value:
For the fake concepts, ratings of satisfaction from the current sample will be used to calculate a "bullshit ability" score that is, the ability to generate a satisfactory definition for a made up concept.

This bullshit ability score will be correlated with the original writers' cognitive ability scores to assess whether bullshit ability may serve as an honest signal of intelligence.

Bullshit ability will also be correlated with participants estimations of the original writers' intelligence. This is to assess whether bullshit ability overtly signals intelligence to those exposed to it, and that this is detectable.

outliers.value: Any other analyses will be listed as exploratory.

dependent.value: Ratings of accuracy, satisfaction of explanation, and estimated intelligence of a definition writer will all be measured using 1-5 scales.

conditions.value:
A group of participants will be given examples from a past sample of participants asked to create definitions of both real and fake concepts. We have raven's matrices and wordsum scores for the original writers of these definitions which serve as an index of the writers' cognitive ability.

The group we collect in the scope of this registration will rate these definitions for how satisfying they are, how accurate they are and to estimate how intelligent the person who wrote them is.

hypothesis.value: Does the ability to create convincing bullshit serve as an honest signal of one's cognitive and social ability?

attributes.title: Inattentional blindness and eyewitness memory
attributes.description: The current OSF registration contains a pre-registration for the project "Inattentional blindness and eyewitness memory - The effect of recall instruction". The pre-registration outlines the design of the study, the hypotheses, the analysis plan, and plans for exclusion of participants. When data is collected, the anonymised dataset and syntax will be included here. Any additional notes or metadata about the project will also be reported in this registration.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Inattentional blindness and eyewitness memory: The influence of recall instruction

other.value:
A number of personality questionnaires are used for the current study as filler tasks (Dissociative Experiences Scale, Modified Tellegen's Absorption Scale, the International Personality Item Pool). Using logistic regression, we will also determine whether these personality factors predict whether participants experience IB or not. 

We will also look at whether there are differences in primary task accuracy between participants who experienced IB for the crime, and those who noticed the crime.

sample.value: We will recruit up to 200 participants for the current study (approximately 30 participants per condition). A power analysis using G*Power revealed that 158 participants were needed with an effect size of .25, and power of .80, for a 2 x 3 ANOVA. However, given the IB condition cannot be randomly allocated, it may be that there are not equal numbers across each of the conditions.

analyses.value:
Rates of inattentional blindness will first be reported. We expect that rates of inattentional blindness will be roughly 50% (i.e. 50% will not notice crime, 50% of participants will notice the crime).

We will then conduct ANOVAs to assess the effect of experiencing IB (yes vs no) and recall instruction on each of the different memory measures. Additionally, we will also run mediation analyses to determine whether memory confidence predicts any of the memory measures (detail, precision, accuracy, acceptance of misinformation/correct post-event information) based on whether participants experienced IB or not.

outliers.value:
Participants will be excluded for the following reasons:

1. Failing to complete the attention-demanding task properly. This is indicated by participants reporting a total count of + or - 2 standard deviations from the mean (Kreitz et al., 2018).
2. Knowing that the study was assessing inattentional blindness when being provided with the video instructions (based off Beanland & Pammer, 2010).
3. Failing to complete the entire study.
4. Failing attention check questions.

dependent.value:
There are two key dependant variables in our study. 

1. Inattentional blindness: naive participants will view a video containing a crime, while completing an attention-demanding task. After the video, participants will be asked questions to determine whether experienced IB for a crime. 

2. Eyewitness memory. We are measuring eyewitness memory by looking at a number of factors relating to memory:
 a. Number of details reported
 b. Precision (no. of fine- and coarse-grain details reported)
 c. Accuracy (no. of correct details reported, divided by total number of details reported)
 d. Acceptance of correct post-event information (no. of correct post-event information items reported)
 e. Acceptance of misinformation (no. of misinformation items reported)
 f. Confidence (confidence ratings for each cued recall question, measured in 10% increments: Rechdan et al., 2016). An average confidence rating for each participant will be created.

conditions.value:
Participants will be categorised according to whether they:
1. Experienced IB for the crime, OR
2. Noticed the crime 
(Note: This cannot be randomly allocated, as it depends upon their own experience of IB when viewing the eyewitness stimulus)

Participants will be randomly allocated to receive 1 of 3 different recall instructions before completing their cued recall:
1. Free report: participants encouraged to use don't know responses, and not to guess
2. Forced report: participants pressured to provide an answer to every question, even if they have to guess
3. No instruction: participants just asked to complete the questionnaire with no additional instruction

hypothesis.value:
The current study is interested in exploring the effects of eyewitness inattentional blindness (IB) on eyewitness memory.

There has been limited research in this area and the existing research has produced mixed findings (Hyman & Wulff, 2017; Rivardo et al., 2011; and an unpublished study within our lab). Methodological differences may account for differences in memory when comparing witnesses who have experienced IB for a crime, and witnesses who have not. For example, in real life there may be pressure put on witnesses to provide responses, given misunderstandings regarding IB (see Levin & Angelone, 2008; Simons & Chabris, 2011). Therefore, one further aim of our study was to determine the effect of recall instruction (free report vs. forced report vs. no instruction) on the memory of witnesses who have experienced IB. 

Overall, it was hypothesised that participants who experienced IB would be less confident in their memory than participants who noticed the crime (Rivardo et al., 2011). They were also expected to provide more course-grain responses in comparison to participants who noticed the crime (Sauer & Hope, 2016), and were also expected to more commonly respond with "don't know" responses than participants who noticed the crime.

We expect that the recall instruction will interact with the effects of IB on eyewitness memory. Specifically, based on a previous study within our lab, we expect that when participants are instructed to freely report (i.e. to not guess), those who have experienced IB will be less detailed, but no less accurate, than those who noticed the crime. However, when forced to report, we expect participants who have experienced IB to be less accurate, and more likely to accept misinformation, compared to witnesses who have noticed the crime (similar to the results of Rivardo et al., 2011). We do not have a clear hypothesis regarding how the no instruction condition will impact the memory of participants who have experienced IB. On the one hand, it is possible that receiving no instruction is similar to being forced to report (Scoboria & Fisico, 2013), and therefore witnesses who have experienced IB may be comparable in their memory when forced to report and when not given a specific instruction. However, given that witnesses who experience IB are expected to be less confident (Rivardo et al., 2011), it may be that witnesses who experience IB may be comparable in their memory when able to freely report and when given no instruction, because they may not feel confident volunteering responses in the absence of a specific instruction (see theory of strategic regulation of memory accuracy: Koriat & Goldsmith, 1996).

We will also look at whether there are differences in primary task accuracy between participants who experienced IB for the crime, and those who noticed the crime.

Participants will be randomly allocated to receive 1 of 3 different recall instructions before completing their cued recall:
1. Free report: participants encouraged to use don't know responses, and not to guess
2. Forced report: participants pressured to provide an answer to every question, even if they have to guess
3. No instruction: participants just asked to complete the questionnaire with no additional instruction
registration_responses.hypothesis:
The current study is interested in exploring the effects of eyewitness inattentional blindness (IB) on eyewitness memory.

There has been limited research in this area and the existing research has produced mixed findings (Hyman & Wulff, 2017; Rivardo et al., 2011; and an unpublished study within our lab). Methodological differences may account for differences in memory when comparing witnesses who have experienced IB for a crime, and witnesses who have not. For example, in real life there may be pressure put on witnesses to provide responses, given misunderstandings regarding IB (see Levin & Angelone, 2008; Simons & Chabris, 2011). Therefore, one further aim of our study was to determine the effect of recall instruction (free report vs. forced report vs. no instruction) on the memory of witnesses who have experienced IB. 

Overall, it was hypothesised that participants who experienced IB would be less confident in their memory than participants who noticed the crime (Rivardo et al., 2011). They were also expected to provide more course-grain responses in comparison to participants who noticed the crime (Sauer & Hope, 2016), and were also expected to more commonly respond with "don't know" responses than participants who noticed the crime.

We expect that the recall instruction will interact with the effects of IB on eyewitness memory. Specifically, based on a previous study within our lab, we expect that when participants are instructed to freely report (i.e. to not guess), those who have experienced IB will be less detailed, but no less accurate, than those who noticed the crime. However, when forced to report, we expect participants who have experienced IB to be less accurate, and more likely to accept misinformation, compared to witnesses who have noticed the crime (similar to the results of Rivardo et al., 2011). We do not have a clear hypothesis regarding how the no instruction condition will impact the memory of participants who have experienced IB. On the one hand, it is possible that receiving no instruction is similar to being forced to report (Scoboria & Fisico, 2013), and therefore witnesses who have experienced IB may be comparable in their memory when forced to report and when not given a specific instruction. However, given that witnesses who experience IB are expected to be less confident (Rivardo et al., 2011), it may be that witnesses who experience IB may be comparable in their memory when able to freely report and when given no instruction, because they may not feel confident volunteering responses in the absence of a specific instruction (see theory of strategic regulation of memory accuracy: Koriat & Goldsmith, 1996).

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

attributes.title: Mental Health of Adolescents During Social Distancing  amid COVID-19
attributes.description:
This pre-registration is for the project of Mental Health of Adolescents During Social Distancing  
 amid COVID-19.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Mental Health of Adolescents During Social Distancing amid COVID-19

other.value: As exploratory purposes, we will also measure the Cognitive Emotion Regulation Questionnaire, Perceived Social Support Scale and Resilience Scale for further analyses.

sample.value: We used an APP in R to conduct a power analysis for the mediation effect based on Monte Carlo confidence intervals (Schoemann, Boulton, & Short, 2017). According to previous literature, we expect the effect size of the correlation between perceived closeness and life satisfaction is 0.41 and their standard deviations are 1.54 and 5.09, respectively (Morry, 2005). Additionally, we expect middle effect sizes for other correlations and set the standard deviation for standardized exposure to the pandemic as 1.0. The target power is set as 0.9 and the confidence level is set as 95%. The calculated outcome of the sample size is 121. For bigger power, we would like to collect double the sample size from power analysis. So the planned sample size is 242. However, since we send out survey to parents and students in a middle school, we would like to collect as many as possible. If the final sample size is more than planned, we will include and analyze all the responses, whereas, if the final sample size is less than planned, we will exhaust all the resources around us to fulfill the sample size.

analyses.value:
Correlations between exposure to the pandemic and 1) life satisfaction, 2) depression, and 3) sleep quality will be tested.
The mediation effects of perceived closeness will be tested via hierarchical regression.

dependent.value:
The exposure to the pandemic COVID-19 is measured by a questionnaire developed to assess the severity of adolescent experiences of COVID-19.
The perceived closeness between adolescents and others will be measured by the Inclusion of Other in the Self Scale. 
Life satisfaction will be measured by the life satisfaction questionnaire which contains six dimensions: friendship satisfaction, family satisfaction, remote course satisfaction, coursework satisfaction, freedom satisfaction, and environment satisfaction. 
Depression will be measured by the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CES-D).
Sleep Quality will be measured by the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index Scale.

conditions.value: Participants will not be assigned to any condition.

hypothesis.value:
1. The exposure to the pandemic is correlated to adolescents' life satisfaction, depression and quality of sleep amid COVID-19.
2. The relationship between exposure to the pandemic and life satisfaction, depression, and quality of sleep is mediated by the perceived closeness between adolescents and others.

study_type_other.value: We are submitting this preregistration on April 12, 2020.  At this point, data have been collected for 144 respondents out of 242 respondents.  Thus, although the data partially exist, almost half of the respondents have yet to be collected, and I have not examined the responses given so far.

attributes.title: COVID-19 and Political Attitudes in India
attributes.description: That existential threats (e.g. terrorism or war) affect a variety of political attitudes and behaviors (e.g. incumbent support, rally effects, attitudes toward minorities) has been well-documented in the literature. Our study aims to extend this research by considering whether a different type of threat -- in this case the spread of the COVID-19 virus -- triggers certain attitudinal changes. Because of the large scope of the virus spread, we theorize that people will perceive the virus as not only being threatening to themselves individually but also to the society as a whole. As a result, we expect that there will be notable changes in people’s attitudes toward how close they feel to and support their society. We therefore aim to assess the impact of the COVID-19 threat on a cluster of features that relate to in-group bonding. These include patriotism, social trust, and social desirability. We plan to examine these relationships via an experimental design where a randomly-assigned portion of survey participants will be presented a COVID-19 related vignette, while others will be shown a placebo scenario. The results of our study will provide a major insight into whether serious but non-violent threats can also induce attitudinal changes that have been well-documented in the research on the impact of political violence on political attitudes and behavior.

q2.value:
Existential but non-violent threats increase the chances that respondents will:
1. Report greater feelings of patriotism.
2. Report greater levels of social trust.
3. Demonstrate greater levels of social desirability.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
To assess whether COVID-19 impacts our dependent variables, we will randomly assign respondents to a condition in which they are asked to read a news vignette about the COVID-19 crisis with an accompanying photo or a condition in which they are asked to read a news vignette about ship recycling with an accompanying photo. This will allow us to estimate the average treatment effects of assignment to the COVID-19 vs. shipping condition on the different outcome variables. 

Our survey has an additional experimental treatment arm unrelated to COVID-19 that is included for the purposes of a separate study.

q7.value:
The assignment to the two conditions (COVID-19 and shipping news stories) will be fully randomized. We will also randomize the sequence in which the post-treatment questions used to measure the dependent variables are asked.

Randomization will be done using Qualtrics survey software.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be identified by the Amazon Mechanical Turk platform. Every time a panel member responds to a survey invitation, even if they do not qualify for the survey, they receive monetary compensation. The population is residents of India aged 18+. The survey will be administered in Spring 2020. We will pay US$0.35 per participant.

q11.value: The target sample size is 450 per experimental group.

q12.value: Sample size was determined by our budget.

question.value: We will manipulate whether the respondent is shown the COVID-19 or shipping vignette.

Attached is a printout of the survey that lists all variables we will measure. The key outcome measures are questions gauging social trust, pride in nationality, and social desirability. The key causal predictor is exposure to the COVID-19 (vs shipping) vignette.

We will estimate the average treatment effects by comparing the means of our outcome variables across the COVID-19 and shipping conditions. To increase precision, we will adjust for pre-treatment demographic covariates using multiple linear regression.

q20.value: The survey includes an instructional manipulation attention check, and we will eliminate those who fail the check. We will also eliminate those who are under 18, those who are not residents of India, and those who opt to have their data excluded after being debriefed.

q22.value: We may examine whether the estimated treatment effects are conditional on demographic factors and other pre-treatment survey responses.

Existential but non-violent threats increase the chances that respondents will:
1. Report greater feelings of patriotism.
2. Report greater levels of social trust.
3. Demonstrate greater levels of social desirability.

q4: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

The assignment to the two conditions (COVID-19 and shipping news stories) will be fully randomized. We will also randomize the sequence in which the post-treatment questions used to measure the dependent variables are asked.

Randomization will be done using Qualtrics survey software.

attributes.title: Complex Emotions Conveyed in Written Sentences
attributes.description: This project includes data from two studies aimed to validate emotion sentences that convey complex emotions of both positive and negative valence.

summary.value: This registration includes copies of the online surveys, both data sets, as well as tables of results for each study.

registration_responses.summary: This registration includes copies of the online surveys, both data sets, as well as tables of results for each study.
